title: 108_s3024
content: The "National Center for Transportation Solutions Act of 2004" establishes the National Center for Transportation Solutions and outlines its duties, organization, powers, and personnel matters. It also authorizes the creation of regional centers for transportation solutions and provides for the appointment of a Director of National Transportation Research. Congress finds that research and development are crucial for a transportation system that meets safety, mobility, economic vitality, efficiency, equity, and environmental protection goals. Despite a 40% increase in overall transportation funding, resources for transportation research and development have remained insufficient, particularly for long-term goals. The competitive award of research funding is best for addressing long-term strategic research needs in transportation. The diversity of research programs poses challenges for regional and university-based centers. Effective priority setting is difficult due to the wide-ranging subject matter. Increasing Federal investment in long-range transportation planning is crucial for meeting safety, mobility, economic vitality, equity, and environmental protection goals in the United States. The curr_chunk focuses on improving transportation research and development by initiating competitive research, coordinating programs, fostering data interchange, and establishing nationwide priorities. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is established as an independent agency in the executive branch of government. It consists of the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board and the Director of National Transportation Research. The Board will exercise the authorities of the Center. The Center's duties include initiating competitive research, coordinating programs, fostering data interchange, and establishing nationwide priorities. The National Center for Transportation Solutions is tasked with developing a long-term national policy for research and development in multimodal transportation. It will support projects with public benefits, provide grants to research institutions, and focus on strategic transportation objectives. The National Center for Transportation Solutions supports long-term transportation objectives by facilitating research data interchange, evaluating government programs, and issuing annual reports. The Director of National Transportation Research must submit an annual report to Congress by January 15 each year, detailing the Center's activities and providing recommendations for research and development in multimodal transportation, including minority views from the National Center for Transportation Solutions Board. SEC. 5. NATIONAL CENTER FOR TRANSPORTATION SOLUTIONS BOARD. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board is established with 16 voting members, including appointments by the Secretary of Transportation, the Director of the National Academies, and the President in consultation with congressional leaders. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board consists of 16 members appointed by various authorities, with members required to have diverse professional backgrounds, represent different regions of the US, and possess relevant skills. Initial appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve 6-year terms with a limit of two consecutive terms. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members have staggered terms, with six members serving for six years, five for four years, and five for two years. Terms do not expire during election years for the President, Senate, or House of Representatives. The National Center for Transportation Solutions Board members have staggered terms. Initial terms can be extended for up to one year. Vacancies do not affect the Board's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Board must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. Meetings are called by the Chair, and a majority of members constitute a quorum. The Board has a Chairman and Vice Chairman. The Board selects a Chairman and Vice Chairman from its members for 2-year terms, with a limit of two consecutive terms as Chairman. The President appoints the Director of National Transportation Research with Senate consent. The Director serves as the chief executive officer of the Center, carries out its authorities, and is a nonvoting member of the Board. The Director serves a six-year term and receives a salary within specified limits. The Center is organized with the President appointing the Director of National Transportation Research with Senate consent. The Director serves as the chief executive officer, carries out authorities, and serves a six-year term. The Center is organized into divisions including Transportation Safety, Environmental Planning, Infrastructure, Intermodal Connections, and Transportation Economics. Each division has a committee to advise the Board and Director, composed of at least five members. Each division committee consists of at least five members, serving two-year terms. The committee elects a Chairman annually and sets its own procedures within Board restrictions. SEC. 8. POWERS OF CENTER. The Board and division committees have the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and enter into contracts to carry out the purposes of the Act. The Board and division committees have the authority to conduct studies with the National Academy of Sciences, use postal services, accept gifts, and publish research results. SEC. 9. CENTER PERSONNEL MATTERS. The Director of the Center may appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. Staff responsibilities include submitting plans, developing budgets, administering programs, and providing support to the Board. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. Staff duties include providing support to the Board, reporting on program progress, and coordinating with other organizations. The Director can set compensation for personnel without restrictions, except that pay rates cannot exceed level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director of the Center has the authority to appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. Staff duties include providing support to the Board, reporting on program progress, and coordinating with other organizations. The Director can set compensation for personnel without restrictions, except that pay rates cannot exceed level V of the Executive Schedule. Any Federal Government employee may be detailed to the Center without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. Volunteer services can also be accepted without regard to certain regulations. SEC. 10. REGIONAL CENTERS FOR TRANSPORTATION SOLUTIONS. The Director shall award grants to establish regional centers for transportation solutions in four regions of the United States. These centers will conduct research projects on regional multimodal transportation issues with long-term significance and clear public benefits. The northeast regional center will be located in a state meeting specific criteria. States must be among the top 5 for traffic congestion based on vehicle miles traveled on National Highway System roads and among the top 10 for congestion in urban areas to qualify for grants. Authorization of appropriations from the Highway Trust Fund for fiscal years 2006 to 2010: $50 million in 2006, $100 million in 2007, $150 million in 2008, $200 million in 2009, and $250 million in 2010.
